As he said this, he suddenly felt very confused and turned pale. Again, he felt that awful feeling he had been experiencing lately, a cold chill that went through him. He realized he had just told a terrible lie and that he would never be able to talk freely again. The pain of this thought was so strong that he almost lost himself for a moment. He got up from his seat and, without looking at anyone, walked towards the door.

“What are you doing?” Razumihin shouted, grabbing his arm.  
He sat back down and started looking around in silence. Everyone was staring at him, confused.  
“But why is everyone so quiet?” he suddenly yelled. “Say something! What’s the point of just sitting here? Come on, let’s talk… We’re all together but sitting in silence… Please, anything!”  

“Thank God; I was worried the same thing as yesterday was starting again,” Pulcheria Alexandrovna said, crossing herself.  
“What’s wrong, Rodya?” Avdotya Romanovna asked suspiciously.  
“Oh, nothing! I just remembered something,” he replied, and then laughed suddenly.  
“Well, if you remembered something, that’s good! I was starting to think…” Zossimov muttered as he got up from the sofa. “It’s time for me to go. I might come back later… if I can.” He bowed and left.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences overwhelming confusion and anguish after realizing he has lied, leading him to feel isolated and unable to communicate freely.
